_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description
The Poet Biorefining-Leipsic facility is located approximately one and
 a half mile northeast of Leipsic, Ohio.  Poet Biorefining-Leipsic?s
 main product is denatured ethanol for use as motor vehicle fuel.
  Production at the facility was initiated in January 2008.  Poet
 Biorefining-Leipsic produces ethanol using the dry mill method.  Corn meal is mixed
 with water and a digestive enzyme to produce starch, which is cooked and
 liquefied.  The resulting mash is cooled and a secondary enzyme is
 added to convert the liquefied starch to fermentable sugars.  Yeast is
 added to the mash to ferment the sugars to ethanol.

The fermented mash (beer) contains about 10% alcohol and is distilled,
 then passed through a dehydration system to produce 200-proof anhydrous
 ethanol.  After final dehydration, the ethanol is collected in two
 2,000,000-gallon storage tanks for addition of a denaturant (natural gas
 condensate, NGC) to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption, per
 federal and state requirements.  The NGC denaturant is stored (primarily)
 in Tank No. 805, which has a capacity of 112,800 gallons
 (approximately 710,000 pounds), and potentially in Tank No. 802, which has a
 capacity of 250,000 gallons (approximately 1,574,000 pounds).  NGC is blended
 in-line with the ethanol and transferred to vehicles for transport
 off-site.  The denatured ethanol is shipped from the facility in tank
 trucks and rail cars.

Chemicals Regulated Under EPA?s Chemical Accident Prevention Program
The NGC denaturant is the only CAPP/RMP regulated chemical which
 exceeds the CAPP quantity thresholds for applicability of the regulation.
  The CAPP/RMP regulated process consists of the NGC denaturant storage
 tank and the associated blending/transfer equipment and piping.  The
 denaturant is added to the ethanol to a concentration of 2% to 5%.  The
 greatest CAPP regulated quantity of denaturant in a tank, vessel or piping
 system is the quantity in the denaturant st

orage tank, located in the
 center containment area of the tank farm.  

Emergency Response Policy and Program
Poet Biorefining-Leipsic is committed to the protection of it
 employees, the surrounding community and the environment from hazardous
 substances used in the ethanol fuel production process.  In the event of an
 emergency, Poet Biorefining-Leipsic?s Emergency Coordinator will direct
 internal response activities to the extent they are within the
 qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable
 precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling of
 materials.  There is no facility emergency response team.  Employees
 within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if such
 response does not pose a danger to their health or safety.  In the
 event of a larger release, it is the policy of Poet Biorefining-Leipsic to
 notify the Leipsic Fire Department and evacuate all employees at the
 facility.

Accidental Release Prevention Program, and Chemical-Specific Prevention
 Steps
Poet Biorefining-Leipsic is committed to protection of the environment
 through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, employee training
 and response preparation.  Public access to the facility from the
 highway is restricted by a gate.  Much of the property is fenced, limiting
 vehicle access.  The plant is fully lighted. Personnel are typically
 on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  There is a multi-camera video
 surveillance system installed at the property, and a general computer based
 alarm system.   The alarm system includes monitoring of the storage
 tanks and denaturant blending system (level control and overfill
 monitors).  The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal
 conditions, which trigger visual control panel alarm lights and audible
 alarms.  All of the facility storage tanks have secondary storage
 containment and are included in the facility Spill Prevention Control and
 Count

ermeasure (SPCC) Plan.

Five-Year Accident History
The facility has an excellent record with regard to minimizing
 recordable and reportable accidents.  There have been no accidents since
 startup of the facility which require inclusion in the five-year accident
 history required by Subpart B of the CAPP/RMP regulation. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Poet Biorefining-Leipsic?s management team is committed to an on-going
 system of reviewing changes in available technologies and any previous
 plant incidents to identify opportunities to improve plant safety.  The
 plant is about to implement a project to upgrade storage tank
 secondary containment.  New computer based maintenance software (Maximo) is
 being implemented which will include automatic scheduling and work order
 generation for all preventative maintenance inspections and tests.
